awd_titl_txt: 2010 Defects in Semiconductors Gordon Research Conference; New London, NH; August 3-8, 2010
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical. A Gordon Research Conference on Defects in Semiconductors will be held at Colby-Sawyer College in New London, NH, August 3-8, 2010. The goal of the conference is to promote fundamental understanding of defects and defect-related phenomena in homogeneous and structured semiconductors. These defects occur, or are introduced, during growth and/or processing of electronic materials. The conference deals with defects in a broad range of bulk and nanoscale electronic materials to assist advancing fundamental understanding in emerging materials such as wide-band-gap semiconductors, doped nanoparticles, and graphene. Electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of bulk, thin film, and nanoscale semiconductors will be discussed in detail. Control of defects in ZnO, nitrides, diamond, and photovoltaics during growth and processing are subjects of several sessions. Interface and extended defects that occur during heteroepitaxial growth of Si, SiC, and GaN will also receive significant attention. There are several sessions focusing on emerging materials, including spintronic semiconductors, ferroelectrics, graphene, and defective/doped nanoparticles. Discussions of atomic-scale imaging techniques, combined with state-of-the-art theoretical methods, will contribute to a fundamental understanding of the atomic-level mechanisms of defects. The conference will provide a forum for interaction between university, government and industrial scientists, and topics that are controversial and/or forward-looking will be emphasized. 

Non-technical. An important impact of this conference will be to increase the attendance of young scientists from under-represented groups. The Gordon conference setting and format encourage interactions on multiple levels, and among senior staff and those early in their careers. Efforts will be made to improve the inclusion of women and minorities in fields related to electronic materials. Along with the opportunity to assess the field and future directions, it is expected that new ties will be established among universities, research institutions, and industry. The requested NSF funds will be used to facilitate participation in the meeting by young faculty, postdoctoral research associates and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
The conference covered the following topics: (1) sp2 CARBON BASED- MATERIALS, (2) DIAMOND, (3) ZINC OXIDE, (4) III-V NITRIDES, (5) INTERFACE, (6) PHOTOVOLTAIC/SOLAR CELL MATERIALS, (7) EXTENDED DEFECTS, (8) NOVEL DETECTION METHOD, (9) FRONTIER IN FIRST-PRINCIPLES DEFECT THEORIES, (10) SPIN AND DEFECTS, (11) FERROELECTRICS, and (12) NANOSTRUCTURES: DEFECTS AND DOPING BOTTLENECK.

    Thirty-four discussion leaders and invited speakers from academia, national labs, and industry in the US, Canada, Mexico, South America, Europe, Africa, and Asia have actively participated in the conference. Most of them have delivered excellent presentations. What is unique about the GRC is the ample discussion time allocated to each presentation. We managed to maintain most of the discussion time and there has not been a single occasion that the discussion ended before the allocated time. During the evening hours, we also ran poster sections: one for Monday and Tuesday and another for Wednesday and Thursday. There were 64 registered posters. The number is about right for in-depth discussions at each poster with significant participation of the conferees. The conference had 103 registered participants. This number is comparable to the number two years ago, and both numbers are significantly higher than the number of participants in previous years. The GRC office ran a survey by all the participants. The return indicates that they overwhelmingly approved and admired the conference. Some even indicated to the Chairs at the end of the conference that this is a perfect conference.

    Intellectual merit: the conference has spurred intense discussions and debates on a number of outstanding questions and issues pertaining to defects in semicondcutors as well as new questions and controversies. It also advanced the awareness and study of defects in all the twelve materials fronts with significant positive impacts for years to come. Broader impacts: there is a large industry presence at the Gordon Conference. Defect physics is at the heart of both the semiconductor industry and photovoltaics. By giving those in industry and academia an opportunity to collaborate so closely, this conference drives technological innovation. This innovation will not only shape the future landscape of the electronic devices available to the public but also advance the forefront of renewable energy. The wide participation and positive feedbacks from the graduate students are strong indications that the meeting has served well their education agenda.
